nodes.bodyText: Don't think we need the return type JSX.Element for components since React.FC defines a return type.

nodes.bodyText:
Think it's more conventional to use type definition isntead of cast
const nodes: { name: string }[] = [];

Let's name Prop interfaces e.g. DependenciesGraphProps. While in apps, it's not so common to export / import props interfaces, it still happens and it prevents having to then rename it at the importer.
Import the methods from React?

These days I prefer using React.useState over import { useState } from 'react'.
The reason for this is that if useState is no longer used in this file in the future, I won't have to check and change the import statement.

I sort of understand the motivation, but it doesn't seem strong enough to use a pattern different from every tutorial on hooks on the web, including official one. We want to make sure the code is accessible to any contributor.
OK!
I guess this is related to my above comment, I think you can just copy-paste the type
Can you make sure all new files that use JSX end with .jsx extension? And to confirm I guess you're waiting to do typescript in another PR?
Should this file be .tsx?

nodes.bodyText: Remove
I think it's better to define / export (or not) this in the file it's used in instead of having generic types.ts files, alternatively Edge.ts would also be idiomatic but overkill I think

nodes.bodyText:
It is not overriding.
AppThunk is an application specific type which is defined to avoid repeating the same type declaration for every thunk function.
https://redux-toolkit.js.org/tutorials/advanced-tutorial#adding-a-reusable-thunk-function-type

nodes.bodyText:
I realized we could think about this in another PR. I think we already have this folder hierarchy
actions
  dependencies-action.js
  trace-action.js
components
  DependenciesPage
  TracePage
reducers
  dependencies
  trace

I would strongly suggest that at some point we move things to something like
components
  DependenciesPage
    index
    actions
    reducer
  TracePage
    index
    actions
    reducer

Action / reducer / component (and now types) are highly coupled so maintenance is simpler by keeping them together rather than separate.
